title: The Dragon Rescuer
description: King Robert's daughter is taken by a dragon. He offers gold to anyone who saves her. Then one day, a friendly dragon arrives at the castle with the princess. The king must now give the reward to a dragon! This leads to friendship between humans and dragons, but the angry first dragon returns for revenge. Together, the king, princess, and the dragon must find a solution.

page1.paragraph1: King Robert sat on his golden throne. His face was sad. His daughter, Princess Lily, was missing. A large, red dragon had taken her three days ago.
page1.paragraph2: "Bring me the royal messenger!" the king called. His voice echoed in the big stone hall.
page1.paragraph3: A small man in green clothes ran into the room. He bowed to the king.
page1.paragraph5: "Make an announcement in every village and town," King Robert said. "Tell everyone that I will give one hundred gold coins to the person who rescues Princess Lily from the dragon."
page1.paragraph6: "One hundred gold coins!" the messenger repeated. His eyes were wide. That was more money than most people saw in their whole lives.
page1.paragraph7: "And add that the brave hero will also receive a small castle by the lake," the king continued. "I want my daughter back, and I will pay any price."

page2.paragraph1: The messenger bowed again. "I will leave immediately, Your Majesty."
page2.paragraph2: After the messenger left, the king's advisor, a wise old man named Thomas, spoke.
page2.paragraph3: "My king, are you sure about this reward? One hundred gold coins and a castle is a lot, even for a princess."
page2.paragraph4: King Robert looked at Thomas with tired eyes. "Lily is my only child, Thomas. She is worth all the gold in the kingdom."
page2.paragraph5: Thomas nodded. "Of course, Your Majesty. I just worry that this reward will attract... the wrong kind of people."
page2.paragraph6: "I don't care who rescues her," the king said. "I just want my daughter back safely."
page2.paragraph7: Thomas bowed. "As you wish, my king."

page3.paragraph1: In her forest prison, Princess Lily was not having a good day. The dragon had put her in a cave on top of a tall mountain. The cave was big and surprisingly clean, but it was still a cave.
page3.paragraph2: "I want to go home!" Lily shouted at the red dragon. "My father will be very angry with you!"
page3.paragraph3: The dragon, who was as big as three horses, looked at her with yellow eyes. "Your father doesn't scare me, little princess. Dragons fear nothing."
page3.paragraph4: "Then why did you take me?" Lily asked. She wasn't really afraid of the dragon anymore. After three days, she had realized that the dragon wasn't going to eat her.
page3.paragraph5: "Because humans need to learn respect," the dragon said. "For too long, your kind has hunted us. Cut down our forests. Built your stone castles on our land."
page3.paragraph6: "That's not my fault," Lily argued. "I've never hurt a dragon in my life."
page3.paragraph7: The dragon made a sound like laughing. "No, but your father has. His knights killed my brother last winter."

page4.paragraph1: Lily was surprised. "My father's knights killed your brother? I didn't know that."
page4.paragraph2: "Of course you didn't," the dragon said. "Humans never talk about the harm they do to dragons. They only tell stories about brave knights killing 'evil' dragons."
page4.paragraph3: Lily thought about this. Could the dragon be telling the truth? Were there stories that she hadn't heard?
page4.paragraph4: "My name is Lily," she said suddenly. "What's your name?"
page4.paragraph5: The dragon looked surprised. "Why do you want to know my name?"
page4.paragraph6: "Because if we're going to talk, I should know what to call you," Lily explained.
page4.paragraph7: The dragon was quiet for a moment. Then it said, "My name is Ember."
page4.paragraph8: "That's a nice name," Lily said. "So, Ember, how long are you planning to keep me here?"

page5.paragraph1: "Until your father learns his lesson," Ember said. "Until he promises to stop hunting dragons."
page5.paragraph2: "And how will he do that if you don't talk to him?" Lily asked.
page5.paragraph3: Ember didn't have an answer for this. The dragon turned away and flew out of the cave, leaving Lily alone.
page5.paragraph4: Lily sat down on the pile of blankets that was her bed. She was a prisoner, but at least Ember gave her food and water. And the view from the cave was beautiful â€“ she could see the whole kingdom from here.
page5.paragraph5: But she missed her father and her home. She wanted to go back to the castle, to her room with its soft bed and warm fireplace.
page5.paragraph6: "I need to escape," Lily said to herself. "Or maybe I need to help Ember and my father understand each other."
page5.paragraph7: But how could she do that when she was trapped in a cave on a mountain?
page5.paragraph8: Little did Lily know, help was coming from a very unexpected place.

page1.paragraph1: Five days after Princess Lily disappeared, a strange visitor arrived at King Robert's castle. The guards at the gate couldn't believe their eyes.
page1.paragraph2: "Is that... a dragon?" one guard asked the other.
page1.paragraph3: "I think it is," the second guard replied. "A blue dragon!"
page1.paragraph4: The blue dragon was smaller than most dragons, about the size of a large horse. It walked toward the gate on four legs. And most surprising of all, Princess Lily was sitting on its back!
page1.paragraph5: "Open the gate!" Lily called to the guards. "This dragon is a friend!"
page1.paragraph6: The guards hesitated. A dragon, a friend? That seemed impossible. Dragons were dangerous creatures that breathed fire and stole princesses. Like the red dragon that had taken Princess Lily just days ago.
page1.paragraph7: "Please, open the gate," Lily insisted. "This dragon saved me from the red dragon. His name is Sky, and he's my friend."

page2.paragraph1: The guards looked at each other, unsure what to do. Finally, one guard said, "I'll go tell the king." He ran into the castle as fast as he could.
page2.paragraph2: A few minutes later, King Robert himself came running to the gate. When he saw his daughter sitting on a blue dragon, his face showed many emotions: surprise, confusion, and most of all, joy.
page2.paragraph4: "Yes, Father," Lily said, smiling. "Thanks to Sky." She patted the blue dragon's neck.
page2.paragraph5: King Robert looked at the dragon with uncertain eyes. "The dragon... saved you?"
page2.paragraph6: "Yes," Lily nodded. "He heard about your reward and decided to help. He's not like other dragons, Father. He's kind and gentle."
page2.paragraph7: The king was silent for a moment. Then he said, "Open the gate. Let my daughter and her... friend enter."

page3.paragraph1: The guards opened the gate, and Sky walked into the castle courtyard. People stopped what they were doing to stare. A dragon in the castle! And not as an enemy, but as a guest!
page3.paragraph2: King Robert helped his daughter down from Sky's back. He hugged her tightly.
page3.paragraph3: "I was so worried," he said. "I thought I might never see you again."
page3.paragraph4: "I'm fine, Father," Lily assured him. "But we need to talk about Ember."
page3.paragraph6: "The red dragon who took me," Lily explained. "He's angry because your knights killed his brother last winter."
page3.paragraph7: King Robert's face became serious. "That dragon attacked a village. We had to stop him."
page3.paragraph8: "Perhaps," Lily said. "But now we have a bigger problem. Ember won't stop until he gets what he wants."
page3.paragraph9: "And what does he want?" the king asked.
page3.paragraph10: "Peace between dragons and humans," Lily said simply.

page4.paragraph1: King Robert looked at Sky, who was sitting quietly in the courtyard. "And what about this dragon? What does he want?"
page4.paragraph2: Before Lily could answer, Sky spoke. His voice was deep but gentle. "I want the reward you promised, King Robert."
page4.paragraph3: Everyone in the courtyard gasped. A talking dragon!
page4.paragraph4: "You... you can talk," the king stammered.
page4.paragraph5: "All dragons can talk," Sky said. "But we rarely speak to humans. They usually try to kill us before we can say hello."
page4.paragraph6: King Robert straightened his back. "You rescued my daughter. According to my announcement, you deserve a reward: one hundred gold coins and a small castle by the lake."
page4.paragraph7: "Just the gold will be fine," Sky said. "I have no use for a castle. Too small for my wings."
page4.paragraph8: A small smile appeared on the king's face. "Very well. One hundred gold coins it is."

page5.paragraph1: The king turned to his advisor, Thomas. "Bring the reward."
page5.paragraph2: Thomas looked worried. "Your Majesty, are you sure? Giving gold to a dragon?"
page5.paragraph3: "A promise is a promise, Thomas," the king said firmly. "This dragon saved my daughter when no human could. He deserves the reward."
page5.paragraph4: Thomas bowed and went to get the gold. While they waited, Lily told her father about her days with Ember, how the red dragon was angry but not cruel.
page5.paragraph5: "He gave me food and blankets," Lily said. "He didn't want to hurt me. He just wanted to send a message."
page5.paragraph6: "A strange way to send a message," the king muttered.
page5.paragraph7: "Dragons have different customs," Sky explained. "Ember is young and impulsive, but his heart is good. He truly believes humans and dragons can live in peace."
page5.paragraph8: "And what do you believe?" the king asked Sky.
page5.paragraph9: "I believe it's worth trying," Sky answered. "That's why I'm here."

page1.paragraph1: The next day, King Robert called a meeting in the great hall of the castle. All the important people of the kingdom were there: knights, nobles, advisors, and even some regular citizens. And, most unusual of all, Sky the blue dragon was there too.
page1.paragraph2: "My loyal subjects," the king began. "Yesterday, a most extraordinary thing happened. My daughter was rescued from a red dragon by this blue dragon, Sky."
page1.paragraph3: People murmured in surprise. Some looked afraid of Sky, who was sitting calmly at the back of the hall.
page1.paragraph4: "But that is not all," the king continued. "Sky can speak our language. And he has told us that all dragons can speak. They have their own society, their own rules, their own customs."
page1.paragraph5: One of the knights, Sir William, stood up. "Your Majesty, with all due respect, dragons are dangerous creatures. They breathe fire and attack our villages."
page1.paragraph6: "Some do," the king acknowledged. "Just as some humans attack and steal. But not all dragons are the same, just as not all humans are the same."

page2.paragraph1: Princess Lily stepped forward. "The red dragon, Ember, took me because he was angry. His brother was killed by our knights last winter. He wanted to send a message."
page2.paragraph2: Sir William frowned. "That dragon was burning crops and scaring people. We had to stop him."
page2.paragraph3: "Did you try talking to him first?" Sky asked from the back of the hall. "Did you ask why he was there?"
page2.paragraph4: Sir William looked uncomfortable. "Well, no. We didn't know dragons could talk."
page2.paragraph5: "And that is the problem," King Robert said. "We have been fighting dragons for generations, but we never tried to understand them. Maybe it's time for that to change."
page2.paragraph6: The hall was quiet as people thought about this. Then one of the farmers spoke up. "But how can we live with dragons? They're so big and scary."
page2.paragraph7: "Not all dragons are big," Sky said. "And not all of us breathe fire. We are as different from each other as humans are."
page2.paragraph8: "I propose a treaty," King Robert announced. "A peace agreement between our kingdom and the dragons."

page3.paragraph1: The idea of a treaty with dragons was so new and strange that no one knew what to say. Princess Lily broke the silence.
page3.paragraph2: "Father, I think that's a wonderful idea," she said. "Sky, do you think the other dragons would agree to a treaty?"
page3.paragraph3: Sky thought for a moment. "Some would. Others might take more convincing. Especially after years of being hunted by humans."
page3.paragraph4: "What about Ember?" Lily asked. "Would he agree to peace?"
page3.paragraph5: "Ember is angry, but he's not unreasonable," Sky said. "If the terms are fair, he might agree."
page3.paragraph6: The king looked at his daughter and the blue dragon. "Then it's settled. We will write a treaty, and Sky will take it to the other dragons."
page3.paragraph7: "And what will this treaty say?" Thomas the advisor asked.
page3.paragraph8: "That humans will not hunt dragons," King Robert said. "And dragons will not attack humans or our villages. We will each respect the other's territory."
page3.paragraph9: "And if there are problems?" Sir William asked. "Misunderstandings?"
page3.paragraph10: "Then we will talk," the king said simply. "Like civilized beings."

page4.paragraph1: Over the next few days, King Robert, Princess Lily, and Sky worked on the treaty. They wrote down rules for both humans and dragons. They drew maps showing which lands belonged to each group.
page4.paragraph2: "What about the mountains?" Lily asked. "Dragons like mountains, but humans mine them for metals."
page4.paragraph3: "We could share them," Sky suggested. "Dragons can have the peaks, where we make our nests. Humans can have the lower parts for mining."
page4.paragraph5: They also decided that each side would choose representatives to meet regularly and discuss any problems.
page4.paragraph6: "I will represent the dragons," Sky said. "At least until others are willing to speak with humans."
page4.paragraph7: "And I will represent the humans," Princess Lily volunteered.
page4.paragraph9: "Yes, Father," Lily said firmly. "I understand dragons better than most humans. I've lived with them, talked with them."
page4.paragraph10: The king smiled proudly at his daughter. "Very well. You will be our ambassador to the dragons."

page5.paragraph1: When the treaty was finished, Sky prepared to take it to the other dragons.
page5.paragraph2: "I'll go to Ember first," he told Lily and the king. "He needs to know you're safe and that you understand his message."
page5.paragraph3: "Tell him I'm sorry about his brother," King Robert said. "And that I hope we can prevent such misunderstandings in the future."
page5.paragraph4: Sky nodded. "I will. But be prepared. Not all dragons will accept this treaty immediately. Some may never accept it."
page5.paragraph5: "The same is true for humans," the king acknowledged. "Change takes time."
page5.paragraph6: Lily hugged Sky's neck. "Be careful. And come back soon."
page5.paragraph7: "I will, Princess," Sky promised. "We are friends now, and dragons are loyal to their friends."
page5.paragraph8: With that, Sky spread his blue wings and flew into the sky. King Robert and Princess Lily watched until he was just a small dot in the distance.
page5.paragraph9: "Do you think it will work, Father?" Lily asked. "Peace with dragons?"
page5.paragraph10: "I don't know," the king admitted. "But thanks to you and Sky, we have a chance."

page1.paragraph1: A week passed with no word from Sky. Princess Lily began to worry. Had something happened to her dragon friend? Had the other dragons rejected the treaty?
page1.paragraph2: She was in the castle garden, thinking about Sky, when a guard came running.
page1.paragraph3: "Princess! Come quickly! There's a dragon approaching the castle!"
page1.paragraph4: Lily's heart jumped with hope. "Is it Sky?"
page1.paragraph5: The guard shook his head. "No, Your Highness. This one is red."
page1.paragraph6: "Ember," Lily whispered. She ran to the castle wall and looked out across the fields.
page1.paragraph7: Sure enough, a large red dragon was flying toward the castle. But he wasn't alone. Sky was flying beside him, and behind them were three more dragons: one green, one brown, and one gold.

page2.paragraph1: "Father!" Lily called, running to find the king. "Dragons are coming! Five of them!"
page2.paragraph2: King Robert was in the throne room, talking with his advisors. He looked up in alarm when Lily burst in.
page2.paragraph3: "Five dragons?" he repeated. "Is Sky with them?"
page2.paragraph4: "Yes, and Ember too," Lily confirmed. "And three others I don't recognize."
page2.paragraph5: The king stood up. "Sound the warning bell, but tell the knights not to attack. These dragons may be coming in peace."
page2.paragraph6: Soon, the castle was buzzing with activity. People climbed the walls to see the approaching dragons. Knights stood ready, but they kept their weapons down, following the king's orders.
page2.paragraph7: The five dragons landed in the large field just outside the castle gates. Sky stepped forward and called out, "King Robert! Princess Lily! We come in peace!"

page3.paragraph1: King Robert and Princess Lily walked out to meet the dragons. The king wore his crown but no armor, showing he came as a ruler, not a warrior.
page3.paragraph2: "Sky," Lily said happily. "You're back! And you brought friends."
page3.paragraph3: "Yes, Princess," Sky said. "This is Ember, whom you know." The red dragon nodded but didn't speak.
page3.paragraph4: "And these are the Dragon Elders: Terra, the green dragon; Boulder, the brown dragon; and Sunfire, the gold dragon. They lead the dragon council."
page3.paragraph5: The three dragons bowed their heads slightly. They were all larger than Sky, and they looked very old and wise.
page3.paragraph6: "It's an honor to meet you," King Robert said, bowing in return. "Welcome to our kingdom."
page3.paragraph7: Terra, the green dragon, spoke in a voice that reminded Lily of rustling leaves. "Sky has told us about your treaty. We have come to discuss it."

page4.paragraph1: The meeting was held in the castle courtyard, as the dragons were too large for the great hall. Chairs were brought for the king and princess, while the dragons sat on their haunches.
page4.paragraph2: "We have read your treaty," Terra said. "It is... interesting."
page4.paragraph3: "Do you agree with its terms?" King Robert asked.
page4.paragraph4: Boulder, the brown dragon, made a rumbling sound. "Some terms are acceptable. Others need changes."
page4.paragraph5: "We are willing to negotiate," the king assured them.
page4.paragraph6: "Before we begin," Sunfire, the gold dragon, said, "there is the matter of Ember's brother. Your knights killed him."
page4.paragraph7: King Robert nodded gravely. "Yes. At the time, we didn't understand that dragons could speak, that they had reasons for their actions. My daughter has told me that Ember's brother was angry because humans had cut down a forest."
page4.paragraph8: "It was his home," Ember said, speaking for the first time. His voice was hot with anger. "Humans destroyed it without thought."

page5.paragraph1: King Robert looked at Ember. "I am truly sorry for your loss. And I recognize that humans have done much harm to dragons over the years. That is why I want this treatyâ€”so such misunderstandings do not lead to more deaths, dragon or human."
page5.paragraph2: Ember's yellow eyes narrowed. "Words are easy, King. Actions are what matter."
page5.paragraph3: "You're right," King Robert agreed. "Which is why, as a sign of good faith, I am giving this land to the dragons." He unrolled a map on a table. "This forest here, and this mountain range. They will be dragon territories, protected by law."
page5.paragraph4: The dragons looked at the map with interest. Terra asked, "And humans will not enter these lands?"
page5.paragraph5: "Only with dragon permission," the king said. "Just as we ask dragons to seek permission before entering human towns."
page5.paragraph6: The Dragon Elders huddled together, speaking in low voices. Finally, Terra turned back to the king.
page5.paragraph7: "We are willing to continue discussing this treaty," she said. "But be warned, human king. If this is a trick, if humans break their word, dragons will not be so forgiving again."
page5.paragraph8: "I understand," King Robert said solemnly. "And I give you my word as king: this is no trick. I truly want peace between our peoples."

page1.paragraph1: The negotiations lasted three days. Both sides made changes to the treaty, adding new terms and clarifying old ones. Princess Lily and Sky helped translate when dragon and human customs were too different to understand.
page1.paragraph2: By the end, they had a treaty that both sides could accept. The final agreement was written on two scrolls: one for the dragons and one for the humans.
page1.paragraph3: On the fourth day, a ceremony was held in the castle courtyard. People from all over the kingdom came to watch. Many had never seen a dragon before, except in battle.
page1.paragraph4: King Robert signed the human scroll with a quill dipped in ink. The Dragon Elders signed their scroll by pressing one claw into soft wax, leaving their unique mark.
page1.paragraph5: "Today marks a new beginning," King Robert announced. "A beginning of peace between dragons and humans. No longer will we fight as enemies. Instead, we will work together as friends."
page1.paragraph6: Terra nodded her great green head. "Many years of mistrust cannot be erased in a day. But this treaty is a good first step."
page1.paragraph7: "And to celebrate this historic day," the king continued, "I proclaim a festival! Let dragons and humans feast and make merry together!"

page2.paragraph1: The festival was like nothing the kingdom had ever seen before. Tables were set up in the castle courtyard and in the fields outside. There was music and dancing and more food than anyone could eat.
page2.paragraph2: At first, people were nervous around the dragons. They stayed far away, watching with wide eyes. But Princess Lily showed everyone that dragons were not to be feared.
page2.paragraph3: "Sky is my friend," she told a group of children. "He saved me from Ember's cave and brought me home safely."
page2.paragraph4: "Can dragons really talk?" one little boy asked.
page2.paragraph5: "We certainly can," Sky answered, making the children jump in surprise. Then they giggled.
page2.paragraph6: "Can you breathe fire?" a little girl wanted to know.
page2.paragraph7: "Some dragons can," Sky said. "I cannot, but Ember can. Would you like to see?"
page2.paragraph8: The children nodded eagerly. Ember, who had been keeping to himself, stepped forward. He looked uncomfortable with all the attention.

page3.paragraph1: "Stand back," Ember warned. The children moved back a few steps, their eyes huge with excitement.
page3.paragraph2: Ember took a deep breath. Then, pointing his head toward the sky, he released a stream of bright orange fire. It shot up like a fountain, illuminating the evening sky.
page3.paragraph3: "Wow!" the children gasped in unison. Then they clapped and cheered.
page3.paragraph4: Ember looked surprised by their reaction. He had expected fear, not delight.
page3.paragraph6: Ember looked at Sky, who nodded encouragingly. So Ember breathed fire again, this time making small circles of flame that floated in the air before disappearing.
page3.paragraph7: More people gathered to watch, amazed by the beautiful display. Soon, Ember was surrounded by admiring humans, both children and adults, all asking questions about dragons.
page3.paragraph8: "Can all dragons breathe fire?" asked one man.
page3.paragraph9: "No," Ember explained. "Some breathe ice. Others can create strong winds. Each dragon has different abilities."
page3.paragraph10: "I think Ember is enjoying himself," Lily said to her father as they watched from a distance.
page3.paragraph11: "It seems so," King Robert agreed. "Who would have thought? A dragon entertaining children in our castle."

page4.paragraph1: As the festival continued, something remarkable happened. Humans and dragons began to talk to each other. They shared stories and songs. They discovered similarities and differences. They began to understand each other.
page4.paragraph2: "Dragons love music just as humans do," Terra told a group of musicians. "Though our songs are different from yours."
page4.paragraph3: "Will you sing for us?" a young woman with a flute asked.
page4.paragraph4: Terra hesitated, then nodded. The green dragon began to sing in a strange, melodic language. The sound was unlike anything the humans had heard before â€“ deep and resonant, yet somehow light.
page4.paragraph5: When Terra finished, there was a moment of silence. Then the musicians began to play, trying to match the melody of Terra's song. Soon, dragon song and human music blended together in a new harmony.
page4.paragraph6: "That was beautiful," the young woman said when they finished. "What was the song about?"
page4.paragraph7: "It tells the story of the first dragon," Terra explained. "How she flew from the stars to make her home on this world, long before humans existed."
page4.paragraph8: Nearby, Boulder was talking with human builders. "Our claws are excellent for carving stone," the brown dragon explained. "We could help you build stronger towers."
page4.paragraph9: "And we could teach you human farming techniques," a farmer offered to Sunfire. "So you wouldn't need to hunt as much."
page4.paragraph10: Everywhere, new ideas were being shared, new friendships formed.

page5.paragraph1: The festival lasted three days. By the end, many humans had lost their fear of dragons, and many dragons had lost their distrust of humans.
page5.paragraph2: On the final evening, King Robert and the Dragon Elders stood together before both their peoples.
page5.paragraph3: "This is just the beginning," King Robert said. "There is much we can learn from each other, much we can accomplish together."
page5.paragraph4: Terra nodded. "For too long, dragons and humans have been enemies. But as this festival has shown, we can be friends, even allies."
page5.paragraph5: "I propose we meet again in one month," the king suggested. "To continue building our friendship."
page5.paragraph6: "Agreed," Terra said. "And in the meantime, Sky and Princess Lily will serve as our ambassadors, helping us understand each other better."
page5.paragraph7: Lily and Sky stepped forward, standing side by side â€“ the human princess and the blue dragon.
page5.paragraph8: "We accept this honor," Lily said. "And we promise to work for peace between our peoples."
page5.paragraph9: "Together, there is nothing we cannot achieve," Sky added, his blue wings spread wide.
page5.paragraph10: As the festival came to an end, Ember approached Lily and Sky. "I was wrong," he admitted. "I thought humans and dragons could never understand each other. But now I see that friendship is possible."
page5.paragraph11: "It is more than possible," Lily said with a smile. "It is happening already."

page1.paragraph1: In the weeks that followed, many changes came to the kingdom. Dragons and humans began to work together in ways that had never been seen before.
page1.paragraph2: Boulder and his dragon family helped the human builders create stronger, more beautiful buildings. With dragon claws carving the stone, towers grew taller and bridges stretched longer.
page1.paragraph3: Sunfire and other gold dragons, who could control heat with great precision, taught blacksmiths new ways to work metal. Soon, the kingdom's tools and weapons were stronger and more finely made than ever before.
page1.paragraph4: In return, humans shared their knowledge of farming, writing, and medicine. Some dragons even came to live near human villages, offering protection in exchange for friendship.
page1.paragraph5: Princess Lily and Sky traveled throughout the kingdom and the dragon lands, helping both sides understand each other better. They became known as the Bridge-Builders, creating connections between two worlds that had once been separated by fear.
page1.paragraph6: King Robert watched all this with pride. His kingdom was becoming stronger and more prosperous. And his daughter was becoming a wise and respected leader.

page2.paragraph1: One evening, as the king was enjoying a quiet dinner with Lily and Sky, a guard burst into the room.
page2.paragraph2: "Your Majesty!" the guard cried. "There's a dragon attacking the village of Oakdale! It's burning houses and fields!"
page2.paragraph3: Sky stood up immediately. "What color is this dragon?"
page2.paragraph4: "Red," the guard said. "A large red dragon."
page2.paragraph5: "Ember?" Lily said, surprised. "But why would he attack a village? He signed the treaty."
page2.paragraph6: "It may not be Ember," Sky pointed out. "There are other red dragons."
page2.paragraph7: "Whoever it is, we must stop them," King Robert declared. "This attack threatens our peace."
page2.paragraph8: "I'll go immediately," Sky offered. "I can fly there faster than your knights."
page2.paragraph9: "And I'm coming with you," Lily said firmly.
page2.paragraph10: King Robert wanted to object, to protect his daughter. But he knew Lily was no longer a child needing protection. She was an ambassador of peace, and this was her duty.

page3.paragraph1: Sky carried Lily on his back as they flew to Oakdale. Even from a distance, they could see smoke rising from the village.
page3.paragraph2: As they got closer, they saw a large red dragon circling above the village, occasionally breathing fire onto the houses below. People were running in panic, trying to escape.
page3.paragraph3: "It is Ember," Lily said sadly, recognizing the dragon. "But why? Why would he do this?"
page3.paragraph4: Sky flew closer. "Ember!" he called out. "Stop this at once! You're breaking the treaty!"
page3.paragraph5: The red dragon turned to face them. His yellow eyes were full of anger. "The humans broke it first!" he roared.
page3.paragraph6: "What do you mean?" Lily asked. "How did they break the treaty?"
page3.paragraph7: "They came to the northern mountains yesterday," Ember explained. "Dragon territory, according to the treaty. They were hunting dragon eggs! My cousin's eggs!"
page3.paragraph8: Lily was shocked. "Are you sure they were from our kingdom?"
page3.paragraph9: "They carried your king's banner," Ember said. "And they wore armor like your knights."
page3.paragraph10: Sky and Lily looked at each other. This was serious. If humans were stealing dragon eggs, it was a terrible crime. But Ember's attack on the village was also wrong.

page4.paragraph1: "Ember, please stop attacking the village," Lily pleaded. "These people had nothing to do with the egg theft. They are innocent."
page4.paragraph2: Ember hesitated. "But someone must pay for this crime."
page4.paragraph3: "And they will," Lily promised. "But not these villagers. Let us investigate what happened. If people from our kingdom stole dragon eggs, they will be punished severely."
page4.paragraph4: "And the eggs will be returned," Sky added. "You have my word as a dragon."
page4.paragraph5: Ember hovered in the air, thinking. Finally, he nodded. "Very well. I will trust you, Princess Lily and Sky. But if justice is not done, if the eggs are not returned, there will be war between dragons and humans again."
page4.paragraph6: "I understand," Lily said. "Now, will you help us put out the fires you started?"
page4.paragraph7: Ember looked down at the burning village. For the first time, he seemed to realize the damage he had caused. "Yes," he said quietly. "I will help."

page5.paragraph1: Together, Lily, Sky, and Ember worked to put out the fires in the village. Sky and Ember used their wings to create strong winds that blew out smaller fires. For larger ones, they carried water from the nearby river.
page5.paragraph2: The villagers were afraid at first, seeing two dragons in their midst. But when they realized the dragons were helping, not hurting, they joined in the effort.
page5.paragraph3: By nightfall, all the fires were out. Several houses had been destroyed, but thankfully, no one had been killed.
page5.paragraph4: "We will rebuild what was lost," Lily told the village leader. "And we will find out who stole the dragon eggs."
page5.paragraph5: When they returned to the castle, King Robert was waiting anxiously. Lily and Sky told him everything they had learned.
page5.paragraph6: "Dragon egg thieves, wearing our colors?" the king said, troubled. "This is disturbing news. Who would do such a thing?"
page5.paragraph7: "Someone who doesn't want peace between humans and dragons," Sky suggested. "Someone who benefits from our conflict."
page5.paragraph8: "Sir William," Lily said suddenly. "He was against the treaty from the beginning. And he leads the knights who patrol the northern borders."
page5.paragraph9: "We cannot accuse him without proof," King Robert cautioned. "But we will investigate. Sky, can you take us to where the eggs were taken from?"

page6.paragraph1: The next day, King Robert, Princess Lily, and a small group of trusted knights followed Sky and Ember to the northern mountains. They found the dragon nest that had been raided. Three eggs were missing.
page6.paragraph2: "Look," Lily said, pointing to the ground. "Footprints. And horseshoe marks."
page6.paragraph3: "And this," one of the knights said, picking up a torn piece of fabric. "This is from our kingdom's uniforms."
page6.paragraph4: King Robert's face darkened with anger. "So it's true. Someone from our kingdom did this. Let us follow the tracks."
page6.paragraph5: The tracks led them to a small, hidden camp in the mountains. As they approached cautiously, they heard voices.
page6.paragraph6: "When do we move the eggs?" someone was asking.
page6.paragraph7: "Tonight," came the reply. "Sir William says we need to make it look like the dragons broke the treaty first. Then we can go back to hunting them."
page6.paragraph8: King Robert had heard enough. He signaled his knights, and they surrounded the camp. Inside, they found three men in the king's colors and, most importantly, three large dragon eggs nestled in straw.

page7.paragraph1: The thieves were arrested immediately. When questioned, they admitted that Sir William had ordered them to steal the eggs and make it look like dragons had attacked humans first.
page7.paragraph2: "He said dragons can't be trusted," one thief explained. "He said they would turn on us eventually, so it was better to strike first."
page7.paragraph3: King Robert was furious. He ordered Sir William to be brought to the throne room at once. When the knight arrived, he looked surprised to see the king with Lily, Sky, and Ember.
page7.paragraph4: "Sir William," the king said sternly, "we have discovered that you ordered the theft of dragon eggs. You have broken the treaty and endangered the peace."
page7.paragraph5: Sir William's face showed no remorse. "Dragons are monsters, Your Majesty. They cannot be our friends. One day, they will turn on us. I was trying to protect our kingdom."
page7.paragraph6: "By starting a war?" Lily asked. "How would that protect anyone?"
page7.paragraph7: "Sometimes war is necessary," Sir William insisted.
page7.paragraph8: "No," King Robert said firmly. "War between humans and dragons has caused nothing but pain and death. Peace is the only way forward."
page7.paragraph9: The king turned to Ember. "The eggs will be returned to their nest immediately. And Sir William will be punished for his crimes."
page7.paragraph10: Ember nodded, satisfied that justice would be done.

page8.paragraph1: Later that day, Sky and Ember carefully carried the dragon eggs back to their nest in the northern mountains. Lily watched as the mother dragon, Ember's cousin, inspected her eggs with relief.
page8.paragraph2: "Thank you," the mother dragon said to Lily. "You kept your promise. You brought justice."
page8.paragraph3: "It is what friends do," Lily replied with a smile.
page8.paragraph4: When they returned to the castle, they found King Robert waiting with the Dragon Elders. The news of the egg theft and Sir William's betrayal had spread quickly.
page8.paragraph5: "This incident could have destroyed our peace," Terra said. "But instead, it has made it stronger. Because when faced with wrongdoing, both humans and dragons chose justice over revenge."
page8.paragraph6: "The treaty holds," King Robert declared. "And our friendship grows."
page8.paragraph7: That evening, as Lily stood on her balcony, Sky landed beside her. "You were brave today," he said. "You faced danger to keep the peace."
page8.paragraph8: "So did you," Lily replied. "And Ember too, in the end."
page8.paragraph9: "Peace is never easy," Sky observed. "It takes courage and understanding from both sides."
page8.paragraph10: Lily looked out over the kingdom, where humans and dragons were beginning to live and work together. "But it's worth it," she said. "Look what we've built together already. Imagine what we can achieve in the years to come."

page9.paragraph1: One year later, King Robert stood on the castle balcony with Princess Lily, watching dragons and humans celebrating the anniversary of the treaty. The kingdom had changed so much in just one year.
page9.paragraph2: New buildings, designed by humans and dragons working together, rose tall and beautiful against the sky. Dragon fire and human ingenuity had created wonders that neither could have made alone.
page9.paragraph3: "I'm proud of you, Lily," the king said, putting his arm around his daughter's shoulders. "You've done more for this kingdom than I ever dreamed possible."
page9.paragraph4: Lily smiled. "I had help. Sky, Ember, and all the others who believed in peace."
page9.paragraph5: "And it all began with a kidnapping," King Robert laughed. "Who would have thought that when Ember took you, he was actually starting something wonderful?"
page9.paragraph6: "Sometimes good things come from unexpected places," Lily said, watching as Sky soared through the sky above the celebration, his blue scales shining in the sunlight.
page9.paragraph7: "Do you remember when I offered a reward for your rescue?" the king asked. "One hundred gold coins and a castle by the lake?"
page9.paragraph8: "Yes," Lily nodded. "And Sky only took the gold. He said castles were too small for dragons."
page9.paragraph9: "Well, I've been thinking," King Robert said. "Sky deserves more than gold for what he's done. I want to name him Royal Dragon Protector of the Realm. First of his kind."
page9.paragraph10: Lily's eyes widened with delight. "He'll be honored, Father. And it will show everyone how important dragons are to our kingdom now."
page9.paragraph11: As Sky landed on the balcony, King Robert made his offer. The blue dragon bowed his head in acceptance.
page9.paragraph12: "I am honored to serve," Sky said. "As friend, protector, and bridge between our worlds."
page9.paragraph13: And so, the kingdom continued to grow and thrive, humans and dragons working together in harmony. All because a princess was kidnapped, a king offered a reward, and a blue dragon decided to help.
